narration.text: Welcome! Today we'll explore projectile motion with a ball thrown upward at 20 meters per second.
Let's start with a ball positioned on the ground.
The ball is thrown upward with an initial velocity of 20 meters per second.
Watch carefully as the ball follows a parabolic path. This curved trajectory is caused by gravity acting downward while the ball maintains its horizontal velocity.
At the highest point of its journey, the ball reaches a maximum height of 20.4 meters above the ground.
Notice that at the peak, the vertical velocity becomes zero, while the horizontal component remains unchanged.
We can calculate this maximum height using the kinematic equation: h equals v-naught squared divided by 2g.
This demonstrates the fundamental principle of projectile motion: horizontal and vertical components act independently of each other.
